name: Overview
main:
In 2014, Islamic State (IS) took over significant portions of Iraqi territory, triggering mass displacement and severe humanitarian needs. After a military stalemate throughout much of 2015, government operations to retake territory from IS were stepped up in 2016 and are ongoing in 2017, aggravating displacement and humanitarian needs, such as health and WASH, particularly in Anbar and Mosul corridors.? Access constraints and human rights violations from all warring parties are of major concern.

Iraq now hosts three million IDPs, one of the largest internally displaced populations in the world.? IDPs and Syrian refugees make up 25% of the population in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I).?

INFORM measures Iraq’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.7/10 and 7/10 rates.?
latest_developments_past:
18/05: Over 300 displaced families from west Mosul coming from Hammam Al-Alil or from east Mosul are reportedly being stopped at checkpoints and turned back. Families are in need of water, food, and health assistance.?

14/05: Over 40,000 people fled western Mosul since ISF opened a new front in northwestern Mosul on 4 May. Between 11 and 14 May, between 5,000 and 17,000 people have reportedly fled west Mosul daily. ?

10/05: The flow of people from Hawija (Kirkuk province) has significantly decreased, possibly due to the increase in IS activities aimed at preventing people from fleeing. An estimated 50,000 – 60,000 people remain in Hawija under IS control.?

10/05: In late April more than 5,500 people fled IS-held Tel Afar for Zummar, an area northeast of the city in the Kurdish Region of Iraq (KR-I).  An estimated 20,000 – 30,000 people remain in Tel Afar and its surrounding areas under IS control.?

08/05: Approximately 127,130 school-aged children have been displaced from Mosul since the Mosul offensive began on 17 October 2016 - up from 78,500 children reported on 12 March.?
